stream_context.summary: Kaze live-models and prototypes Course 11 (“Bowser’s Oil Rig”), shows a new global lighting tweak, debugs a broken zip-line, and discusses upcoming multiplayer work and overall project scope.

development_findings.summary: Course 11 is an industrial oil-rig zone with numerous custom moving assets: lateral platforms, in-out pistons, rotating cranes, shrinking platforms, zip-lines, rotating oil drums, and cannons for inter-building travel.
Kaze added a camera-based additive light (inspired by Mario Odyssey) to brighten dynamic objects and improve scene readability, especially in dark areas.
development_findings.quote: I added the light coming from the camera back. Now all the moving objects are kind of colored in by the camera.

development_findings.summary: A months-old collision-optimization bug offset ceiling ray-casts by 160 units, breaking zip-line detection; Kaze located the faulty brackets and restored correct behavior within minutes.
development_findings.quote: See that’s the thing with me. I never test my code… months later a bug just occurs and it’s like, yeah, now I have to prove that I didn’t mess up.

development_findings.summary: Custom ‘optimized libultra’ and several micro-optimisations boost N64 performance (e.g., Koopa Wave Cove now ~42 FPS); however, a new clip-ratio tweak causes distant-triangle melting and needs investigation.
Kaze plans to spend a two-week company vacation at the end of June adding split-screen multiplayer; possible daily dev streams during that sprint.
development_findings.quote: My company actually gives me two weeks vacation at the end of June and in those two weeks I might add multiplayer with split-screen.

development_findings.summary: Design stance: fundamental mechanics (e.g., new swimming physics) will not be user-toggleable; Kaze prefers a single authored vision.
development_findings.quote: I’m kind of against giving players options… I don’t think I want an option for that one.

development_findings.summary: The current cannon reticle uses eight matrices for four triangles; Kaze will replace it with a cheaper display-list to reduce overhead.
Remaining main levels outlined: a Comic-Book world, Wild-West Valley (Course 12), a Casino world, and one unspecified area.
Retro Pipe for Course 11 is planned as a Smash 64 ‘Board the Platforms’ homage, matching the heavy platform-focus of the stage.
Lighting, fog, and palette for Course 11 are being iterated; target scheme blends royal purple steel, orange sky-tint, blue oil, and Biobak’s distinct pink highlights.

context_findings.summary: Kaze values player freedom and dislikes overt guidance such as trajectory lines for cannons.
context_findings.quote: Games should be about experiencing freedom. If I give you a line to move along you’re just following instructions.

context_findings.summary: He avoids exhaustive testing, accepting later bug hunts as an efficiency trade-off.
context_findings.quote: I never test my code. It saves me a lot of time and usually it works.

context_findings.summary: Frustration with intrusive Twitch ads prompted permanent migration to YouTube for streams.
context_findings.quote: On YouTube at least I can decide whether there’s ads or not… on Twitch I find it unwatchable with all the ads.

context_findings.summary: Kaze’s day job allows paid ‘team-building’ game sessions; he jokingly labels himself a professional Fortnite player.
context_findings.quote: I’m literally paid to play Fortnite… I have a good excuse.

context_findings.summary: Personal dynamic: casual, teasing banter with wife/animator Zeina; they discuss stream logistics and household matters on air.

biobak.summary: Suggested the reddish-orange oil coloration and provides key texture work, including 32 k texture library.

badub.summary: Composes the custom soundtrack; most stream music is Badub’s original, with some Mario remixes.
badub.quote: All of the OST is custom made by Badub, so it actually is not copyrighted.

zeina.summary: Produces character animations; current focus is Bowser’s walk-cycle and balloon-hanging poses for the pending boss fight.

key_stories.title: Zip-Line Bug Hunt
key_stories.summary: During testing, Mario no longer grabbed zip-lines. Kaze traced the issue to a collision optimisation added months earlier.
key_stories.challenge: Zip-lines stopped functioning across all levels.
key_stories.process: Inserted death breakpoints, printed ceiling heights, identified an 80-unit Y-offset caused by misplaced brackets in the new ray-cast loop.
key_stories.outcome: Fixed in ~5 minutes; reaffirmed risk of his ‘no test’ coding style.
key_stories.key_quote: I never test my code… months later a bug just occurs and it’s like, yeah, now I have to prove that I didn’t mess up.

key_stories.title: Brightening the Game
key_stories.summary: Player feedback said Mario appeared too dark. After watching Mario Odyssey footage, Kaze re-implemented a camera-light to brighten dynamic objects.
key_stories.challenge: Scenes were hard to read; Mario was shaded heavily.
key_stories.process: Added back camera-space light vector alongside level light, tweaked values, verified across multiple levels.
key_stories.outcome: Levels look brighter and more readable; cave stages less grim.
key_stories.key_quote: Even dark cave levels now look not that grim, I find.

key_stories.title: Switch from Twitch
key_stories.summary: Kaze abandons Twitch streaming due to mandatory ads that even hit subscribers.
key_stories.challenge: Unskippable ads harming viewer experience and his own enjoyment.
key_stories.process: Tested YouTube streams for a month, confirmed control over ad insertion, informed audience.
key_stories.outcome: Permanent move to YouTube; occasional weekly streams with potential daily marathon during multiplayer sprint.
key_stories.key_quote: I find Twitch personally unwatchable with all the ads.
